title: SAAB JAS‑39 Gripen
description: Sweden’s lightweight multirole fighter aircraft, designed for air superiority, attack, and reconnaissance missions.
history:
The SAAB JAS‑39 Gripen was developed by Sweden in the 1980s–1990s as a flexible multirole combat aircraft to replace the Saab 35 Draken and Saab 37 Viggen. Its name reflects its unified mission roles: Jakt (fighter), Attack (strike), and Spaning (reconnaissance). Development emphasized agility, low operating cost, and adaptability to operate from short runways and dispersed bases. The first prototype flew in 1988 and the initial production version entered Swedish service in the mid‑1990s. Over time the platform has evolved through multiple upgrades and an advanced next‑generation follow‑on designed to incorporate modern avionics, radar, propulsion, and weapons integration.

Early developmental efforts used a demonstrator aircraft to test avionics and future growth technologies, feeding into later improvements. Production variants expanded capability, NATO interoperability, and export appeal. The most recent evolution, known as Gripen NG (Next Generation), serves as the baseline for the modern JAS‑39E and JAS‑39F variants with enhanced sensors, engine, and payload capability. The Gripen family has been exported to several air forces and continues to serve as a backbone of Sweden’s air defense and multirole mission sets.
